ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to best work in a laboratory. how to set up effective and achievable goals in lab. how to consider the data that we are gathering.
Experience and knowledge navigating biological lab environment
Lab research methods, data analysis, scientific writing, presentation, and more

I developed further experience working collaboratively in a research lab, planning my time proactively and responding to results accordingly. I also gained further practice writing and giving presentations about my work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this course is very well-designed to benefit students novel to research. I feel like it was adequately paced to match a variety of levels of experience.

This course is really whatever you make it. The course features a few assignments to keep you on track & check in on progress without becoming overbearing. Prof. Schilling was readily available if ever needed.

Strengths include Dr. Schilling who has done a wonderful job providing students with the necessary guidance and tools to succeed. Weaknesses: 10 hours each week is not sufficient time to gather data in lab, I often found myself staying upwards, close to 20 hours a week in lab.

A major strength is the overall flexibility of the course, which allows students to plan their time in lab accordingly while still encouraging them to think carefully about how to structure the semester as a whole. Another strength is the optional enrichment opportunities offered, including both in-person sessions as well as helpful links that were provided through Slack.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It certainly is nice to have a structured lab experience during a semester.

Yes. I strongly recommend to any student with an interest in working in academic research. I think Professor Schilling is a very good instructor in terms of offering insight about writing research papers and academia.

Yes. I think that this course is a great way to fit lab time into your schedule. That said, this course is really whatever you make of it. Prof. Schilling is always available by email/slack for help, but your work in lab will determine the quality of your experience. As far as MB&B goes, 10 hours/week is not a whole lot of time, so I felt as though progress was especially slow at times.

Yes! If you already work in a lab this is a great opportunity for an elective. While I would say the workload is high with a 10hr/week expected commitment to your lab research, the class assignments themselves amounted to a much smaller workload than the average class.
Yes! a great course to take if you're doing research already and want to get credit.

I would definitely recommend this course! It's an excellent way to make time for lab work in a semi-structured environment, and can be especially helpful for those without much prior experience in scientific writing/presentation (provided they take advantage of the guidance offered). That said, it's important to be sure that you're interested in your research project and committed to spending a significant amount of time in lab -- if not, this may not be the class for you.
